awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Physically Based Models of Atomic Layer Deposition for High-Throughput Reactor Design
awd_abstract_narration:
With new energy, electronics, and consumer product applications, and the emergence of highthroughput reactor designs, Atomic Layer Deposition (ALD) is set to become a major thin-film manufacturing tool. Deposited using an alternating sequence of exposures to gas-phase precursors that would otherwise spontaneously react, ALD allows for the controlled deposition of a wide range of ultra-thin films at relatively low temperatures and potentially perfect conformality. Despite the upsurge in ALD process and equipment development, research on modeling deposition mechanisms and reaction kinetics in particular, continues to lag efforts devoted to new precursor chemistries and reactor designs. Because ALD is by its essential nature a completely dynamic process with no equivalent to steady-state deposition, the objective and primary intellectual merit of this proposal is to develop physically based models describing both ALD reaction rates and the changes occurring on the growth surface using transition-state (absolute rate) theory concepts. To achieve this objective, we identify three distinct subprojects to be pursued in this proposal: 

1. Transition state rate model development for both reference and industrially relevant ALD reactions, combined with efficient numerical techniques to compute limit cycle solutions corresponding to continuous ALD reactor operation enabling optimization of the cyclic process.

2. Development of micro- and nano-scale precursor transport models in the form of ballistic transport simulations coupled to the new surface reaction models, and spatial discretization techniques to simulate the time-evolution of the growth surface position.

3. Validation of the reaction kinetics and ballistic transport models using reactors of the proposal industrial partner and dissemination of the rate modeling methods to the ALD community. The basic surface science research, numerical techniques, and reactor process research necessary to address the research goals described will potentially have a broad impact by contributing fundamentally to thin-film process engineering. Likewise, the physically based modeling methods developed are intended to be distributed to the ALD research and development community, further accelerating the range of applications of this manufacturing technology. The proposed research program will offer a unique educational opportunity for the engineering graduate students involved, giving them exposure to the scientists and engineers developing the next generation of ALD processes at Cambridge NanoTech. 

Furthermore, with support of this proposal, the PI will continue to develop hands-on demonstrations of the products of thin film engineering which will be used for middle- and high-school level outreach programs.

por.por_cntn:
With new energy, electronics, and consumer product applications, and the emergence of high-throughput reactor designs, Atomic Layer Deposition (ALD) is set to become a major thin-film manufacturing tool. Deposited using an alternating sequence of exposures to gas-phase precursors that would otherwise spontaneously react, ALD allows for the controlled deposition of a wide range of ultra-thin films at relatively low temperatures and with atomic-level precision.

Despite the upsurge in ALD process and equipment development, research on modeling deposition mechanisms and reaction kinetics in particular continues to lag efforts devoted to new precursor chemistries and reactor designs. Because ALD is by its essential nature a completely dynamic process with no equivalent to steady-state deposition, the primary research activities supported by this grant focused on developing physically based models describing both ALD reaction rates and the changes occurring on the growth surface using transition-state (absolute rate) theory concepts. The most significant outcomes and intellectual merit of this research program are summarized below.

1) Dynamic modeling: A significant effort in developing physically based mathematical models of ALD reaction rates was supported by this grant. In collaboration with computational chemists, quantum chemical information was used to predict elementary ALD reaction rates from statistical mechanics methods. Models for industrially relevant ALD processes were produced by our research group and subsequently used by industrial practitioners for reactor optimization and design.

2) Reaction graph analysis: Simulations based on the modeling work described above revealed an important characteristic of many ALD systems - widely ranging time scales associated with the dynamics of the deposition process, resulting in numerically unstable simulations and unphysical predictions. To assess the ALD model structure, a graph-theoretic approach for reaction network analysis was developed by our research group. The resulting framework for analysis was shown to be an effective probe for structural defects prior to performing any time-intensive simulation studies.

3) Anomalously high growth-per-cycle: During the period of this grant, a partnership with NASA's Goddard Spaceflight Center was established to assess the potential of ALD for depositing protective coatings for space-based astronomy applications. During preliminary testing of an ALD reactor built for this collaboration, students (undergraduate and graduate) supported by this grant found unusually high film growth rates for the test alumina ALD process - the most highly studied of all ALD systems. Through systematic modeling efforts made possible by the research supported by this grant, we were able to trace the high growth phenomenon to its physical source. The resulting paper became the highest-downloaded paper for that journal in the month that it was published.

4) Products and broader impact: With support of this grant, one undergraduate, one MS, and two PhD students were supported, seven refereed papers were published, numerous invited talks were presented, new algorithms and open-source reaction network software were created, and a new mode of ALD reactor operation was discovered that provides a new route to high throughput ALD manufacturing.
